definition: Sichuan/the state of Shu in Sichuan at different periods/the Shu Han dynasty (214-263) of Liu Bei 劉備|刘备 during the Three Kingdoms
short name for Sichuan 四川[Si4 chuan1] province/one of the Three Kingdoms 三國|三国[San1 guo2] after the Han dynasty, also called 蜀漢|蜀汉[Shu3 Han4], situated around what is now Sichuan province
country/nation/state/national/CL:個|个[ge4]
surname Guo

sentences.english: Chengdu was the capital of Shu during the Three Kingdoms.
sentences.chinese: 成都是三國時期蜀國的首都。

sentences.english: Therefore, Wu and Shu united to defend his attack.
sentences.chinese: 因此吳國和蜀國聯合起來抗曹。

sentences.english: In ancient times, Sichuan was called Shu Kingdom, and the transportation wasn’t good at that time.
sentences.chinese: 古時候，四川成爲蜀國，交通十分不便。

sentences.english: At the end of Shang dynasty and the beginning of Zhou dynasty, the ancient Shu entered the Duyu dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 商末周初，古蜀國由魚鳧王朝跨入了杜宇王朝。

sentences.english: The river system in Wenjiang has given birth to the ancient Shu Kingdom culture.
sentences.chinese: 溫江河系孕育了古蜀國的文化。

sentences.english: He was so great that everyone in the state of Shu loved him.
sentences.chinese: 他是一個好丞相，所有的蜀國人都很愛戴他。

sentences.english: If Shu rule all the land, chopping and not cut is right.
sentences.chinese: 若是蜀國一統天下了，斬與不斬就都是對的了。

sentences.english: The Jinsha Ruins may have been the political and cultural centre of the ancient Shu Kingdom.
sentences.chinese: 金沙遺址可能是古代蜀國的政治和文化中心。

sentences.english: Completed all of the Shu Alliance Battles in Conquest Mode.
sentences.chinese: 在無雙模式中完成所有蜀國的聯盟戰役。

definition: Shu Han (c. 200-263), Liu Bei's kingdom in Sichuan during the Three Kingdoms, claiming legitimacy as successor of Han

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
tossed about by the wind and rain (idiom)/(of a situation) unstable
Sima Yan (236-290), founding emperor of Jin dynasty 晋 after the Three Kingdoms period, reigned 265-290 as Emperor Wu of Jin 晉武帝
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty
Wei State (407-225 BC), one of the Seven Hero States of the Warring States 戰國七雄|战国七雄/Wei State or Cao Wei 曹魏 (220-265), the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms
peasant revolt
Emperor Xian of Han (181-234), the final Han emperor, set up by Dong Zhuo 董卓, reigned 189-220, forced to abdicate 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕
the Qin army (model for the terracotta warriors)
the state of Chu, one of the most important of the small states contending for power in China between 770 and 223 BC, located around present-day Hubei
Sima Zhao (211-265), military general and statesman of Cao Wei 曹魏[Cao2 Wei4]
An-Shi Rebellion (755-763) of 安祿山|安禄山[An1 Lu4 shan1] and 史思明[Shi3 Si1 ming2], a catastrophic setback for Tang dynasty
Sunwu county in Heihe 黑河[Hei1 he2], Heilongjiang
Liu Yu, founder of Song of the Southern dynasties 劉宋|刘宋[Liu2 Song4], broke away from Eastern Jin in 420, reigned as Emperor Wu of Song 宋武帝[Song4 Wu3 di4]
utterly defeated/routed/crushed/to collapse (of army)
